Class for input scaled Bernstein functions

Source: R/allClass-S4.R, R/allInitialize-S4.R, R/allShow-S4.R, and 1 more
SumOfBernsteinFunctions-class.Rd

Class for the sum of two Bernstein functions

# S4 method for SumOfBernsteinFunctions
initialize(.Object, first, second)

# S4 method for SumOfBernsteinFunctions
show(object)

# S4 method for SumOfBernsteinFunctions
valueOf(object, x, difference_order = 0L, n = 1L, k = 0L, cscale = 1, ...)

Arguments

.Object

An object: see the “Initialize Methods” section.
first

Derives from BernsteinFunction.
second

Derives from BernsteinFunction.
object

An object deriving from LevyBernsteinFunction (for levyDensity) or CompleteBernsteinFunction (for stieltjesDensity).
x

Non-negativ numeric vector at which the iterated difference of the Bernstein function is evaluated.
difference_order

The order of the alternating iterated forward differences taken on the Bernstein function (\(j\) in the representation).
n

Non-negative numbers for the binomial factors.
k

Non-negative numbers for the binomial factors.
cscale

Positive number, the composit scaling factor.
...

arguments to specify properties of the new object, to be passed to initialize().

Details

Bernstein functions are stable under addition, i.e. if \(\psi_1\) and \(\psi_2\) are two Bernstein functions, then $$ x \mapsto \psi_1(x) + \psi_2(x) , x>0, $$ is also a Bernstein function.

Functions

  • initialize,SumOfBernsteinFunctions-method: Constructor

  • show,SumOfBernsteinFunctions-method: Display the object.

  • valueOf,SumOfBernsteinFunctions-method: Calculates the iterated differences of the Bernstein function, see valueOf()

Slots

first

The first summand (derived from BernsteinFunction).

second

The second summand (derived from BernsteinFunction).

See also

BernsteinFunction, valueOf()

Examples

SumOfBernsteinFunctions()

#> An object of class "SumOfBernsteinFunctions"
#> 	 (invalid or not initialized)
first_bf <- LinearBernsteinFunction(scale = 0.2)
second_bf <- AlphaStableBernsteinFunction(alpha = 0.5)
SumOfBernsteinFunctions(first = first_bf, second = second_bf)

#> An object of class "SumOfBernsteinFunctions"
#> - first:
#> 	An object of class "LinearBernsteinFunction"
#> 	- scale: 0.2
#> - second:
#> 	An object of class "AlphaStableBernsteinFunction"
#> 	- alpha: 0.5
